facts.text: The respondent has a structure abutting on the Yacoob Road, which is about 12 feet wide. On the other side of the road is an open nallah running parallel to the road, about 45 feet in width, providing passage for dirty water and rain water to the creek during November to May.
Government of Maharashtra demolished a portion of Varala Dam in May 1963, causing water stored in the lake to pass through the nallah to the creek.
Appellant commenced work of laying cement slab across the nallah in the second week of June 1963. Centering work to support and settle the slab continued in position till first week of July 1963.
Appellant prepared plan for narrowing the nallah in front of respondent's shop without provision for passage of additional rain water from Varala lake catchment area.
Existence of centering work and cement slab constituted grave obstruction against passage of rain water through nallah.
Appellant neglected to keep nallah passage free and unobstructed by construction work and debris for safe passage of rain water at commencement of monsoon.

Heavy rain at Bhiwandi on 5th, 6th and 7th July 1963. Due to centering, slab, shrubs, debris, water course completely blocked; rain water from catchment beyond dam, Bhiwandi, Nizampur accumulated to dangerous heights, flooding area adjoining nallah.
High Court found appellant had knowledge in April 1963 of demolition of Varala Dam above 6 feet ground level.
Appellant completed laying slab between Teen Batti bridge and Habsanali bridge after April 1963 with knowledge of dam demolition.
Appellant narrowed water-way near Teen Batti bridge insufficient for discharge from increased catchment area due to demolition.
Appellant with knowledge narrowed water passage, put slab, did not remove centering at Lendi bridge.
Appellant allowed accumulation of garbage and debris obstructing water passage.
Nallah runs south to north to creek; five bridges over it. Portion between Habsanali bridge and Lendi bridge covered with concrete slab in 1963.
Heavy rain on 4th, 5th, 6th July 1963; water accumulated at southern end of Habsanali bridge, entered surrounding area; water two feet deep in respondent's factory for three days.

Narrowing water-way and slab at Habsanali bridge ill-timed; should have commenced after Varala Dam reconstruction or provided sufficient water-way for 0.9 sq. miles catchment at 3 inch per hour rainfall.
Centering work should have been removed before monsoon; no trees, bushes, debris, garbage allowed to collect obstructing passage.
Retention of centering and negligence in not clearing debris was principal cause of flood.
Respondent filed suit against appellant Municipality for Rs. 1,00,012/- damages due to flood from gross negligence. High Court decreed Rs. 54,560/- with 6% interest per annum.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Municipality acted in good faith under Section 167 of the Bombay District Municipal Act, so as to be protected from liability, or whether its actions were reckless and thus mala fide.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant guilty of gross negligence: narrowing nallah without provision for extra water, obstruction by centering/slab, failure to clear construction/debris before monsoon, leading to flood on 5-7 July 1963.

court_reasoning.text: High Court findings confirmed: appellant knew of dam demolition, narrowed waterway insufficiently, retained centering, allowed debris, causing flood.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Narrowing ill-timed; should have provided for increased flow or waited; principal cause was retention of centering and uncleared debris.

court_reasoning.text: Section 167 protects acts done in good faith. 'Good faith' means done honestly, even if negligent. But distinction between honest blunder/carelessness and not honest (reckless disregard).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Citing Jones v. Gordon: aware of possible harm yet doing nothing is reckless, equal to mala fides.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant aware of possible harm from dam demolition and works, yet did nothing: reckless, hence mala fide, unprotected by s.167.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Something more than negligence required; here, awareness without action.

holdings.text: Municipality's actions were reckless disregard of consequences, hence mala fide, not protected by Section 167 of Bombay District Municipal Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between honest negligence and reckless disregard (not honest); awareness of harm without inquiry/action is mala fide.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay District Municipal Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides protection for acts done in good faith; does not protect reckless/mala fide acts.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay General Clauses Act, 1904
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'done in good faith' as done honestly, whether negligently or not.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'done in good faith' as done honestly, whether negligently or not.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed, upholding Bombay High Court decree of Rs. 54,560/- with 6% interest in favour of respondent for damages from flood caused by Municipality's reckless negligence.
outcome.relief_granted: None additional; High Court decree upheld.

key_quotes.text: Being aware of possible harm to others, and acting in spite thereof, is acting with reckless disregard of consequences. It is worse than negligence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines threshold for mala fides under good faith protection.

key_quotes.text: In the facts of this case we hold that the defendant was aware of possible harm and yet cared to do nothing about it. The action was, therefore, reckless, and therefore in the eye of law mala fide.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding denying protection under s.167.
